verses.text: After I returned home, on our festival day, I prepared a good meal and reclined to eat.
verses.comment: Tobit observes the Jewish feast day and prepares a meal according to custom. Faithful celebration of the feasts connects to Israel’s worship and identity.

verses.text: When I saw so much food before me, I said to my son Tobiah, 'Go, my child, and find any poor person among our people who remembers the Lord. Bring him back so he may eat with me. I will wait until you return.'
verses.comment: Tobit’s concern for the poor reflects the law’s command to care for the needy. There is also a foreshadowing of Christ’s teaching on feeding the hungry (cf. Matt. 25:35).

verses.text: So Tobiah went out to look for someone from our people. But when he returned, he said, 'Father!' And I replied, 'What is it, my child?'
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes obedience and the close relationship between Tobit and his son, echoing biblical calls to honor parents (Ex. 20:12).

verses.text: He answered, 'Father, one of our people has been murdered! He has been thrown into the marketplace.'
verses.comment: Discovery of a murdered man connects to the law about caring for unburied dead (Deut. 21:1). Tobit’s reaction reflects the importance of burial within the tradition.

verses.text: Immediately, I left my meal and removed the body from the marketplace, placing it in a room until sunset so that I could bury him after dark.
verses.comment: Tobit’s willingness to risk ritual impurity shows reverence for God’s law and human life. It also parallels burial of Jesus by Joseph of Arimathea (Matt. 27:57-60).

verses.text: When I returned, I washed myself and ate my food in sorrow.
verses.comment: Tobit follows ritual purification customs after contact with the dead. His sorrow prefigures the Christian call to mourn with those who mourn (Rom. 12:15).

verses.text: Then I remembered the prophecy of Amos: 'Your festivals will be turned into mourning, and all your songs into lamentation.' I wept.
verses.comment: Tobit’s knowledge of Scripture demonstrates deep faith. He sees his experience through the lens of prophecy, an example of discerning God’s will through Sacred Scripture.

verses.text: The people who lived in Nineveh said, 'He is no longer afraid! He is still burying the dead.'
verses.comment: Tobit’s actions are courageous and countercultural. He fulfills the law even under persecution, paralleling the later Christian call to serve God despite opposition.

verses.text: But I hid myself. When they found out about what I was doing, I was afraid for my life.
verses.comment: This reflects the experience of many righteous men and women in Scripture, who acted in faith despite danger. Foreshadows the persecution of early believers.

verses.text: Yet, when night fell, I went out, dug a grave, and buried him.
verses.comment: Tobit’s persistence in works of mercy provides a model for Christians of all times. Burying the dead is later counted among the spiritual and corporal works of mercy.

verses.text: My neighbors mocked me, saying, 'He is still not afraid! He has already been hunted for such things before, and now he is running away again.'
verses.comment: Public scorn for righteous deeds is a common biblical theme. Tobit endures insult for God, foreshadowing the path of the saints who persevere in acts of charity.

verses.text: On the same night, after I had buried him, I came home, washed myself, and went to sleep in the courtyard with my face uncovered because it was hot.
verses.comment: Tobit again observes ritual purity after burial. His sleeping in the open sets the stage for the next event, which holds spiritual significance beyond the merely physical.

verses.text: But as I was sleeping, warm droppings from a sparrow fell into my eyes, and they became inflamed. I went blind.
verses.comment: Tobit's sudden blindness connects to biblical themes of suffering and divine testing. This parallels later miracles of healing the blind (John 9:6-7). Suffering here is not a punishment, but a mysterious trial permitted by God for a greater purpose.

verses.text: For four years I could not see. All my relatives were troubled, but my wife Anna earned our livelihood by doing women's work.
verses.comment: Anna’s faithful support in hardship highlights the dignity of family life and cooperation within marriage. Faithfulness amid suffering, done out of love, prefigures the deeper unity found in Christian marriage (Eph. 5:31-33).
